entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling on a motorcycle, scooter, or similar motorized vehicle for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument. You can purchase this pass in advance at www.yourpassnow.com.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle Pass

data.directionsInfo:
Two highways enter the parks. Hwy 180 from Fresno leads east to Kings Canyon National Park, then continues 30 miles east to Cedar Grove. Hwy 198 from Visalia leads east to Sequoia National Park via Three Rivers. Inside the parks, Highway 198 becomes the Generals Highway, which connects 198 to 180. 

Vehicles over 22-feet long should enter the parks via Highway 180.

In winter, the Generals Highway between the parks often closes. Chains may be required on park roads.

No roads cross these parks east to west.

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake Ranger District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument for one year from the month of purchase. The pass admits all passengers in a private vehicle and is non-transferable. You can purchase this pass in advance at www.yourpassnow.com.
entrancePasses.title: Sequoia & Kings Canyon Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo:
Because of the extreme elevation range in these parks, weather conditions vary widely between areas. 

In summer, the sequoia groves have comfortable temperatures and the foothills are hot and dry. Snow lingers on high-mountain passes well into summer.

In fall, some areas close or reduce their hours. Winter brings snow to sequoia groves and rain to the foothills. Be prepared for tire chain requirements. 

Spring is a great time to hike in the foothills and snow begins to melt at higher elevations.
data.name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon

operatingHours.description: These parks are open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Rarely, extreme weather conditions may cause roads into the parks to be closed.
operatingHours.name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks

data.description: This dramatic landscape testifies to nature's size, beauty, and diversity—huge mountains, rugged foothills, deep canyons, vast caverns, and the world's largest trees. The parks lie side by side in the southern Sierra Nevada east of the San Joaquin Valley. Weather varies a lot by season and elevation, which ranges from 1,370' to 14,494'.

emailAddresses.description: If you have general questions about Tonto National Monument and the cliff dwellings, please send us an email. We will respond as soon as possible.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee applies to everyone 16 and older. Children under 16 are free. Tonto National Monument accepts all interagency federal public lands passes in places of the entrance fee. These Include the Annual, Senior, Access, Military, and Fourth Grader passes.
entranceFees.title: Per Person Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: The cliff dwellings at Tonto National Monument are roughly two hours from the Phoenix metro area, located in the Tonto Basin. The monument is off AZ Highway 188 near Roosevelt Lake. The nearest major towns are Globe (30 miles) and Payson (50 miles). See our Directions page for recommendations on the best way to drive here from the larger metro areas of Arizona.
data.weatherInfo: Weather during the summer can be extremely hot. It is typically 10 degrees Fahrenheit cooler than Phoenix. Winter weather may create hazardous conditions on the roads to Tonto National Monument. Severe thunderstorms may lead to a closer of the hiking trails.
data.name: Tonto

operatingHours.description: The hours for the National Monument are 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. everyday except December 25 when the Monument is closed. Please arrive before 4:00 p.m. to hike to the Lower Cliff Dwelling. During the months of June, July, and August, the Lower Cliff Dwelling Trail begins reduced summer hours from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m., please begin the hike before 12 p.m. (noon).
operatingHours.name: Tonto National Monument

data.description: The Salado Phenomena, 700 years ago, blended ideas of neighboring Native American cultures to emerge a unique and vibrant society. Tonto National Monument showcases two Salado-style cliff dwellings. Colorful pottery, woven cotton cloth, and other artifacts tell a story of people living and using resources from the northern Sonoran Desert from 1250 to 1450 CE.

data.description: The Tule Lake National Monument includes both the the Tule Lake Segregation Center, the largest and most controversial of the sites where Japanese Americans were incarcerated during World War II, and Camp Tulelake, which was first a Civilian Conservation Corps camp, then an additional facility to detain Japanese Americans, and finally a prisoner of war camp.

data.directionsInfo: Tumacácori National Historical Park is located off of Exit 29 of Interstate 19, forty-five miles (80 kilometers) south of Tucson, Arizona, and eighteen miles (26 kilometers) north of Nogales, Arizona.

entrancePasses.description: Covers pass holder(s) plus three adult guests. Kids under 16 are always free. Photo ID of either pass holder required. Valid for 12 months from month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Tumacácori Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo: Located above the heat of the low desert, Tumacácori National Historical Park is in the mesquite highlands, close to 3,300 feet in elevation, where temperatures are five to ten degrees cooler than Tucson or Phoenix. Visiting the park in this moderate climate is pleasurable during any season of the year but remember to prepare accordingly. Bring layered clothing and drink plenty of water.
data.name: Tumacácori

operatingHours.description: Visitor Center and mission grounds are closed on Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. The Anza Trail is open 24/7.
operatingHours.name: Hours of Operation

data.description: Tumacácori sits at a cultural crossroads in the Santa Cruz River valley. Here O’odham, Yaqui, and Apache people met and mingled with European Jesuit and Franciscan missionaries, settlers, and soldiers, sometimes in conflict and sometimes in cooperation. Follow the timeworn paths and discover stories that connect us to enduring relationships, vibrant cultures, and traditions of long ago.

images.altText: panorama of mission church with green grass and clouds
images.title: Tumacácori on a Summer Day
images.caption: A summer day yields beautiful colors and a striking scene on the mission grounds.

images.altText: folklorico dancers in front of church
images.title: La Fiesta de Tumacácori
images.caption: The Fiesta de Tumacácori, held annually in December, has over 40 years of history and hundreds of years of heritage.

images.altText: long paved sidewalk leads to adobe mission church
images.title: Visiting Tumacácori
images.caption: Modern facilities like paved sidewalks and restrooms complement a visit to this site's rich history.

images.altText: milky way in sky over dimly lit bell tower
images.title: Milky Way over the Bell Tower
images.caption: Several times each year, the park opens late to invite visitors to experience dark night skies and the legacy of astronomy priest Padre Eusebio Francisco Kino.

images.altText: ranger and visitors looking at church facade
images.title: Visitors on a Mission Tour
images.caption: Guided mission tours explore the hidden treasures and untold stories of Tumacácori's past.

data.directionsInfo:
Car
From Interstate 5, take the Highway 44 West exit toward Downtown Redding and Eureka. From Downtown Redding, follow Highway 299 west toward Eureka for approximately 8 miles to reach the Visitor Center.
 
Plane
Commercial air service is available to Redding California located approximately 16 miles from Whiskeytown. Rental vehicles are available.

data.weatherInfo: Whiskeytown NRA is in a Mediterranean climate, which means hot, dry summers followed by cool, wet winters. Summer temperatures often reach the upper 90's to lower 100 degrees Fahrenheit, as well as the occasional thunderstorm. Winter brings snow to the upper elevations (only occasionally down to the lake level of 1,200'), and rain and ice.
data.name: Whiskeytown

operatingHours.description:
Hours
 
The Visitor Center is open daily except on Wednesday, November 21st the Visitor Center will close at at 1 p.m. In addition to November 25th and 26th for Thanksgiving, December 10 from 11:30 to 2:30, December 24th and 25th for Christmas, December 31st and January 1st for New Years Day. 

•Hours are 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.

Seasons
 
The park is open year-round, 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Whiskeytown National Recreation Area

data.description: Whiskeytown Lake’s crystal-clear water is perhaps the most recognized feature of the park. However, water-based recreation is only a part of what the 42,000-acre Whiskeytown National Recreation Area (NRA) has to offer. Visit waterfalls, hike through rugged mountains, explore California Gold Rush history, and observe post-fire ecology in action. Your national park is calling...

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures at White Sands vary greatly throughout the year. Summer time temperatures can be very hot. Winters are mild with cool evenings. Spring time is the windy season. Fall is very enjoyable with mild daytime and night time temperatures.

operatingHours.description: Monument hours change throughout the year. Gates always open at 7:00 am with closing hours changing with the seasons. Standard hours are typically Memorial Day through Labor Day. View the exceptions below to see the 2016 monument hours.

data.description: Rising from the heart of the Tularosa Basin is one of the world's great natural wonders - the glistening white sands of New Mexico. Great wave-like dunes of gypsum sand have engulfed 275 square miles of desert, creating the world's largest gypsum dunefield. White Sands National Park preserves a major portion of this unique dunefield, along with the plants and animals that live here.

images.altText: Aerial of white sand dunes.
images.title: Aerial of Dunefield
images.caption: The dunes at White Sands cover 275 square miles of the Tularosa Basin.

images.altText: Close up view of ripples on a dune.
images.title: Ripples
images.caption: The wind shapes and moves the dunes as a whole but gives each individual dune the texture of ripples.

images.altText: Dunes colored orange by sunset.
images.title: Sunset Colored Dunes
images.caption: Sunsets are one of the most popular times to visit White Sands. Visitors can experience sunset every day of the year.

images.altText: Cottonwood trees with orange leaves.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: Fall is a wonderful time to visit as most of our plants with leaves change beautiful colors.

images.altText: Grey shadows on dunes.
images.title: Shaded Dunes
images.caption: As the sun changes its angle through the sky it allows shadow to roll across the dunes.

data.directionsInfo:
You can drive to Yosemite all year and enter via Highways 41, 140, and 120 from the west. Tioga Pass Entrance (via Highway 120 from the east) is closed from around November through late May or June. Hetch Hetchy is open all year but may close intermittently due to snow.

Please note that GPS units do not always provide accurate directions to or within Yosemite.

data.weatherInfo: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)
data.name: Yosemite

operatingHours.description: Yosemite National Park is always open. Reservations are not available or required to enter the park. However, during summer, it's best to arrive by mid-morning to avoid traffic.
operatingHours.name: Yosemite National Park

data.description:
Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra.

First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.altText: Mountains reflecting in water
images.title: Glen Aulin
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.altText: Mountains surrounding a lake.
images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.

images.altText: Glaciated valley with vertical cliffs.
images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.altText: Granite dome with trace amounts of snow.
images.title: Half Dome
images.caption: Half Dome is one of the most recognizable granitic formations in the world.

images.altText: Massive cliff of El Capitan reflected in the Merced River
images.title: El Capitan
images.caption: El Capitan rises over 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.altText: Very tall sequoia trees in a sequoia grove.
images.title: Giant Sequoia Tree
images.caption: Giant Sequoia trees are the largest living things (by volume) on the planet. Though not the tallest trees, one feels miniature in their presence..
